refsection.title: Overview
refsection.para: PhysicalProperty is a subclass of &Property; and a base class of FluxProperty and EqnProperty, the classes that define the physics behavior of materials. Users should not derive new classes from PhysicalProperty directly.

title.code: int integration_order(const CSubProblem *subproblem, const Element *element) const

refsection.para: When &oof2; converts an equation like or to matrix form, it replaces the &fields; by an expansion in the &elem;'s shape functions Ni(x), multiplies everything by a test function (which is another shape function, Nj(x)), and then integrates over the entire mesh (i.e, over each element). Divergence terms are integrated by parts, which replaces the test function by its derivative.

The integration over the elements is done by Gaussian quadrature. To choose the appropriate number of Gauss points, it's necessary to know the polynomial degree of the integrand in x and y. Generally, higher order polynomials require more points. Choosing an integration order that is too large will slow down the calculation. Choosing one that is too small could lead to incorrect results.

The method integration_order(), which must be defined in each PhysicalProperty class, returns the polynomial degree of the integrand. The degree depends on the structure of the integrand and on the polynomial degrees of the shape functions and their derivatives. These can be obtained from Element::shapefun_degree() and Element::dshapefun_degree().

Sometimes the polynomial degree depends on whether or not a &field; has an out-of-plane part. Consider elasticity or thermal conductivity. The &flux; is proportional to the gradient of a &field;, and the &field; \(\phi\) can be expanded in shape functions. SchematicallyThe index i stands for a combination of node indices and field component indices. This is just a schematic representation.
\[ \sigma({\bf x}) = \mathrm{modulus}\cdot\sum_i {\partial\over\partial\bf x} N_i({\bf x})\phi_i({\bf x}_i) \]
where \({\bf x}_i\) is the position of &node; i.
Taking the divergence, multiplying by a test function Nj and integrating (by parts) over the area yields
\[ \int d{\bf x}\, N_j({\bf x}) \nabla\cdot\sigma({\bf x}) = - \mathrm{modulus}\cdot \sum_i \int d{\bf x}\, {\partial N_j({\bf x})\over\partial{\bf x}}\, {\partial N_i({\bf x})\over\partial{\bf x}} \phi_i + \mathrm{boundary terms} \]
Since there are two factors of the shape function derivatives, the polynomial degree is twice the the degree of the derivative of the shape functions.

However, this isn't quite correct. If the &field; has an out-of-plane part,
\[ \psi({\bf x}) \equiv (\partial\phi_x/\partial z,\, \partial\phi_y/\partial z,\, \partial\phi_z/\partial z) \]
it is also expanded in shape functions,
\[ \psi({\bf x}) = \sum_i N_i({\bf x}) \psi_i({\bf x}_i) \]
so the &flux; is
\[ \sigma({\bf x}) = \mathrm{modulus}\cdot \sum_i \left( {\partial N_i({\bf x})\over\partial x}\phi_x + {\partial N_i({\bf y})\over\partial y}\phi_y + N_i({\bf x})\psi_z \right) \]
Taking the divergence and integrating by parts, the last term in will have one factor of
\(\partial N({\bf x})/\partial{\bf x}\)
from the divergence and one factor of
\(N({\bf x})\)
from the flux, which is a higher order polynomial than the first two terms. Therefore for this &Property;, integration_order() should be
int Elasticity::integration_order(const CSubProblem *subp, const Element *el) const { if(displacement->in_plane(subp)) // in-plane: two derivatives of N(x) return 2*el->dshapefun_degree(); // out-of-plane: one N(x) and one derivative of N(x) return el->shapefun_degree() + el->dshapefun_degree(); }

warning.para: Do not compute the shapefunction's derivative's degree by subtracting 1 from the shapefunction's degree. For purposes of Gaussian integration, the degree of the shapefunction is sometimes less than its actual polynomial degree. For example, the linear quadrilateral shapefunction \((1-x)(1-y)/4\) can be integrated exactly with a single Gauss point at (0,0), although its polynomial degree is 2. For this function, both shapefun_degree() and dshapefun_degree() return 1.
